abstract.text: Creates a new ACL entry with the given characteristics, and adds it to an access instance.

inlineContent.text: SecKeychain is deprecated

inlineContent.text: The access instance to which to add the information.
An array of
instances identifying apps that are allowed access to the keychain item without user confirmation.
Set this parameter to
to indicate that any app can use this item. Pass an empty array to indicate that there are no trusted apps.
The human readable name to be used to refer to this item when the user is prompted.
A set of prompt selector flags. See
for possible values.
A pointer the method uses to return the new
instance.
A result code. See

The ACL entry returned by this method includes a list of trusted apps, the name of the keychain item as it appears in user prompts, the prompt selector flag, and a list of one or more operations to which this ACL entry applies. By default, a new ACL entry applies to all operations. Use the
method to set the list of operations for an ACL entry.
Starting in macOS 10.13.1, for added security, the system ignores the
property of an ACL object and always prompts for the keychain password when asking the user whether to add an app to the list of trusted apps.
The system requires exactly one owner ACL entry in each access instance. The
method fails if you attempt to add a second owner entry. To change owner access controls, use the
function to find the owner entry (the only one with an authorization tag of
) and the
method to change it as needed.

abstract.text: Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
An opaque type that represents information about an ACL entry.
Creates a new ACL entry with the given characteristics, and adds it to an access instance.
Sets the application list, description, and prompt selector for a given ACL entry.
Sets the authorization tags for a given ACL.
An opaque type that identifies a keychain item’s access information.
Retrieves selected ACL entries from a given access instance.
Bits that define when a keychain should require a passphrase.
An opaque type that contains information about a trusted app.
Change an access control list entry.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
A reference to an immutable array object.
A reference to a CFString object.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
